plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2011 Results Conference Call. I'm Stephanie, the Chorus Call operator. I would like to remind you that all participants will be in listen-only mode and the conference is being recorded. After the presentation, there will be a Q&A session.
At this time, it's my pleasure to hand over to UBS.

Good morning, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter Results Presentation. This morning, Sergio Ermotti, our CEO, will present the highlights of our full-year results and the fourth quarter results. Then Tom Naratil, our CFO, will present the fourth quarter results in detail. After that, we'd be very happy to take your questions, and, first of all, we'll take questions from analysts and then from journalists.
Before I hand over to Sergio, I'd like to draw your attention to this slide, which contains our cautionary statement with regard to forward-looking statements, and I'd ask that you read it carefully.
With that, I'd like to hand over to Sergio.

Thank you, Caroline. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. At our Investor Day in November, we outlined a strategy for UBS that centers on our preeminent Wealth Management businesses and our Universal Bank in Switzerland and that builds on the strength of a more focused and less capital-intensive Investment Bank, as well as our diversified Global Asset Management business. This strategy is supported by our industry-leading capital position and requires us to significantly reduce risk-weighted assets, which ultimately will enable us to deliver increasingly attractive returns to our shareholders.

2011 was not an easy year for the industry nor for UBS. The European debt crisis, U.S. budget issues and weak economic growth put pressure on markets and on the confidence of our clients. We also faced our own challenges, with the unauthorized trading incident. Despite this, we have made real progress in a number of businesses and delivering in the strategic objectives we set out at Investor Day.

Let me outline our five key achievements so far. First, we maintained our position as the best capitalized bank in our peer group. We ended the year with a Basel 2.5 tier-1 capital ratio of 16%, up 330 basis points in the year. Our phased-in Basel 3 common equity ratio was 10.8% at the year end, and this is a firm basis on which to build towards our 13% target.

Our determination to increase our capital base in 2011 also led to an increase of 16% in our book value per share, at CHF14.29, and a 20% increase in our tangible book value per share. Despite the stresses associated with the macro environment, our funding and liquidity positions also remained strong throughout 2011.

Secondly, we decisively reduced risk-weighted assets. We reduced Basel 2.5 risk-weighted assets by 10% over the year, and in the fourth quarter, Basel 3 risk-weighted assets were cut by about CHF20 billion, to CHF380 billion. In total, the Investment Bank reduced risk-weighted assets by CHF26 billion. Around CHF18 billion of the reduction was in our legacy portfolio, mostly reflecting sales of student loan auction rate securities and the remainder of the reduction came from the core Investment Bank businesses. This means we are well on track and on our way to achieving the risk-weighted asset target we set for the Investment Bank in 2012.

Thirdly, we attracted CHF42 billion of net new money, an improvement of around CHF55 billion on the previous year. Our Wealth Management businesses drove most of the improvement, attracting over CHF35 billion of net new money compared with outflows in the previous year. Global Asset Management also attracted increased net new money, including CHF12 billion from third parties.

Let me also highlight that in our Retail & Corporate business in Switzerland in 2011, we attracted the highest level of net – of new client assets from our retail customers since 2007. All of this is a testament to the loyalty and the trust of our clients, the recognition of our financial strength and the hard work of our employees.

Fourth, profitability. Today, we announced a net profit attributable to shareholders for 2011 of CHF4.2 billion, diluted earnings per share of CHF1.10 and a pre-tax profit of CHF5.5 billion. Let me highlight the progress we have made in our Wealth Management businesses and Retail & Corporate in Switzerland, which are central to our strategy. Together, these three businesses increased their pre-tax profit by 29%, to CHF5.1 billion. This is an excellent performance in a year characterized by low client activity levels and low interest rates.

Global Asset Management contributed over CHF400 million in pre-tax profit, down 17% in a year where many of our clients chose the safety of cash instead of actively invested funds. Global Asset Management continues to be of vital importance to the implementation of our strategy and to our clients around the world.

For the full year, the Investment Bank recorded a pre-tax profit of CHF304 million, down from CHF2.2 billion in the prior year. The financial performance, however, does not tell the full story, as the business made strategic improvements that, unfortunately, did not get the attention they deserved because of the unauthorized trading incident.

Fifth and lastly on costs, as you know, we are currently implementing our CHF2 billion cost reduction program announced last July. Head count was down by over 1,100 in the fourth quarter, and we expect to see consequent reduction in costs over the course of 2012.

In 2011, our cost base fell CHF2.1 billion, or 9%. Two-third of this reduction was a result of lower compensation expenses, mostly reflecting cuts to bosses, in particular in the Investment Bank, reflecting weaker performance and as a result of the unauthorized trading incident.

Tom will go through the detailed numbers, so I will speak to the headline figures. Our 2011 bonus pool is down 40%, and this compares to a 13% decline in our operating income. I believe this is a clear illustration of our efforts to ensure that rewards are better aligned with performance and to balance the interest of staff and shareholders both in the short and the longer term.

Looking ahead, we expect continuing weak economic growth and macro issues to influence global markets, and clients will look to us for advice and solutions. Although markets are challenging, they present us with significant opportunities to deliver our expertise and capabilities, provided we stay close to our clients, understand their needs and deliver on the full promise of our strategy.

This is the absolute priority of the year for the banking in 2012 and, to do this effectively, we must leverage our superior capital position and our overall financial strength. Markets will, to some extent, dictate what wealth is created and the speed at which net new money can be delivered. Regardless of market condition, we will maintain our discipline on gross margin and we will not seek inflows at any price.

There are two areas where we are determined to drive further improvements, on cost efficiency and the reduction of risk-weighted assets to further improve our capital position. On cost, as I said, we expect to see more of the benefit of our CHF2 billion cost containment program later this year.

We will continue to actively monitor markets and, if conditions deteriorate materially, we are prepared to take action to reduce our cost base further. But as I say at our Investor Day, our capacity to further cut costs in a tactical way is limited, so we must focus on strategic changes which go to the heart of our organizational design and structure, consistently improving efficiency as to become part of our corporate DNA. And we are working on the next phase, which will reshape our cost base in the years to come.

As you have seen, we have already made clear progress on risk reduction and we aim to maintain our momentum over the course of the year. 2012 is a year of transition for the group and, particularly, for the investment bank, as we fundamentally reshape our business. Building on our capital position is, therefore, a priority for 2012, and we are determined to meet our risk reduction target in full and on time.

One of the key commitments we made last November was to drive improved returns in the business and make UBS more attractive to our shareholders. Although we expect markets to remain challenging for the foreseeable future, I'm confident that we can achieve the targets we have set. Underscoring my confidence, I want to close by reiterating our intention to propose a dividend of CHF0.10 per share at our AGM this year. This will be a starting point for a progressive return policy we intend to implement as we execute on our strategy.

Before I hand over to Tom, I'd like to reiterate the key achievements of the bank for 2011 and on the fourth quarter. We remain the best capitalized bank amongst our peer, with a sizably reduced risk-weighted asset particularly in Q4, and this provide a good basis for delivering our risk-weighted assets target reduction for 2012.

Net new money for the year improved CHF55 billion and all our asset-gathering businesses had positive net new money in the fourth quarter. We recorded a pre-tax profit of CHF5.5 billion for the year, with a 29% increase in the combined profits of our Wealth Management businesses and Retail & Corporate. We reduced costs by over CHF2 billion and, lastly, we intend to propose a CHF0.10 dividend for the year.
With that, I thank you for your attention, and I will now turn it over to Tom Naratil to take you through the quarter's result in more details.

Thanks, Sergio, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to take you through the details of our results for the fourth quarter of 2011. We recorded a net profit of approximately CHF400 million and a pre-tax profit of approximately CHF600 million in the fourth quarter.

Despite the challenging market conditions, we were encouraged by a number of positive developments this past quarter. To name a few, we continued to attract net new money in our Wealth Management businesses, Retail & Corporate had a resilient performance and Global Asset Management profits were up nearly 50% quarter-on-quarter. In the Investment Bank, we saw another quarter of strong performance in our macro and advisory businesses. As Sergio said, we continued to make progress in risk-weighted asset reduction, implementation of our cost reduction program is on track and our capital, liquidity and funding positions remain sound.

Before I get into the details of the results, I'd like to make a few important points on the environment in the fourth quarter. Despite continued uncertainty around the Eurozone sovereign debt crisis and a consistently weak economic outlook, equity markets experienced lower volatility, particularly at the end of the quarter. Market conditions continued to weigh on client confidence, leading to low client activity levels and a significant reduction in trading volumes.

Most major indices closed at higher levels compared with the end of the third quarter, which had a positive effect on our invested assets. The Swiss franc depreciated against the U.S. dollar and the British pound, continuing the trends seen in the third quarter after the Swiss National Bank's decision to set a minimum exchange rate in early September. This positively impacted our invested asset levels, improving fee income and other revenue streams in non-Swiss franc currencies. While this depreciation was helpful on the revenue side, it had the offsetting effect of increasing our cost base.

In the fourth quarter, we focused our efforts on reducing risk-weighted assets, in particular in our legacy book. We are ahead of the plan we outlined at our Investor Day and we're confident our success so far puts us in a position to meet our targets. This chart illustrates the progress we've already made.

Before I comment on the specific reductions we achieved, let me remind you that these figures are on a pro forma Basel 3 basis. Also note that as we finalized the composition of the legacy portfolio in December, total legacy RWAs were revised to approximately CHF80 billion. This is approximately CHF10 billion higher than the estimated number we provided to you earlier and is offset with a reduction in the core Investment Bank.

The total for the group was reduced by CHF20 billion to approximately CHF380 billion despite the weakening franc against the dollar. This decrease does not include the anticipated net CHF17 billion benefit from the roll-off of the market-risk RWAs related to the unauthorized trading incident, as we'd already deducted it from the pro forma numbers at the beginning of the period.

CHF18 billion of the decrease is related to a reduction in our legacy portfolio, mostly the result of a sale of CHF1.4 billion of U.S. student loan auction rate securities at or near our marks. The remaining reduction of CHF8 billion was in the core IB and was a result of lower market risk in our trading book. With this, we've already achieved one-third of our planned reduction for 2012.

There were clearly offsetting increases, the most significant of which relates to increased CVA charges related to the counterparty credit risk on derivatives transactions, as our model takes external credit rating inputs for the credit quality of the counterparty. In the fourth quarter, we witnessed several downgrades of sovereigns and financial institutions, which increased the CVA charge by approximately CHF5 billion.

We ended the quarter at CHF212 billion, and our target is to reduce to CHF190 billion by the end of 2012. There may be some fluctuation as we deploy risk in a disciplined way in the core IB if market conditions improve. However, we expect a more sustained reduction as we make progress exiting inventory in some of our less attractive businesses.

Reduction of Basel 3 RWAs is one of our key strategic initiatives. We remain focused on disciplined execution, particularly in the legacy portfolio. We transferred this portfolio from the Investment Bank to the Corporate Center in the fourth quarter. More details are shown on the next slide.

Starting with the first quarter of 2012, we'll report the legacy portfolio as part of a separate segment in the Corporate Center. IB assets transferred include auction rate securities, monoline-protected assets, asset-backed securities and some long-dated rates positions totaling approximately CHF27 billion of balance sheet assets and CHF23 billion of positive replacement values at the end of December 2011.

At the end of the year, this portfolio accounted for CHF62 billion of pro forma Basel 3 RWAs, CHF7 billion of which related to U.S. student loan auction rate securities. We've also transferred all contingent liabilities associated with legacy assets and businesses, as you can read in our quarterly report.

In addition to the assets transferred from the Investment Bank, this segment will include our option to buy the equity in the SNB StabFund, which is currently valued at CHF1.6 billion. Half of this amount is currently deducted from Tier 1 capital, but will be converted to approximately CHF20 billion of RWAs under Basel III.

On this slide, you'll find a breakdown of our results by division. I'd like to comment first on the Corporate Center and then move on to the business divisions. The Corporate Center reported a loss of CHF273 million, mostly due to a loss of CHF129 million related to the revaluation of our option to buy the SNB StabFund's equity. Expenses were CHF121 million after allocations to the business division. Our tax rate for the quarter was higher than expected, at 32%. However, the effective tax rate for the year was 17.5%, which is in line with our guidance. I'll provide more details on our tax expense later in this presentation.

Both of our Wealth Management businesses saw a continued net new money inflows in the fourth quarter, which, coupled with higher equity market levels at the end of the quarter and currency movements, led to higher invested assets. At the end of the year, invested assets stood at CHF1.5 trillion. Our scope and geographic diversification enable us to weather continued uncertainty in the markets relatively well, as demonstrated by the resilience of our revenues despite low client activity. This is a clear testament to the strength of our unrivaled franchise.

Additionally, Wealth Management Americas maintained its number one position in invested assets and revenues for a financial advisor, which is a function of its high net worth and ultra-high net worth focused client strategy. Wealth Management reported a pre-tax profit of CHF468 million compared to CHF540 million in the third quarter, excluding CHF433 million in gains from the sale of our strategic investment portfolio as well as CHF85 million in restructuring charges in the third quarter. I'll exclude these items for the remainder of the commentary.

Revenues of almost CHF1.7 billion were 4% lower than last quarter due to lower client activity as well as lower interest income previously generated by the strategic investment portfolio. The loss of these revenues more than offset the positive net interest impact of higher loan and deposit volumes, which were driven by the strengthening of the U.S. dollar versus the franc. Net fee and commission income declined due to lower client activity and a shift of client assets into cash and cash-like products as clients sought safety in an uncertain market environment.

Trading income, adjusted for the reclassification in the third quarter, decreased about 7%, mostly due to unusually high levels of client FX trading in the summer months. Expenses were roughly flat after adjusting both quarters for restructuring charges booked for our cost reduction program. Our client advisor head count decreased slightly in the quarter, partly due to our efforts to trim underperforming advisor ranks. However, we did and will continue to hire client advisors in our strategic growth areas of APAC and the emerging markets.

Net new money inflows were CHF3.1 billion, as we benefited from several large flows during the quarter. Net inflows continue to come from our key growth areas of Asia-Pacific and the emerging markets, as well as globally from ultra-high net worth clients. Our European onshore business reported net inflows which more than offset net outflows in the offshore business, mainly from countries neighboring Switzerland.

Our European net new money result also includes the CHF600 million in outflows we had previously flagged related to the departure of client advisers who joined the firm as part of a past acquisition in Germany. These outflows are now complete. In Switzerland, we saw net outflows of CHF1.8 billion, partly reflecting seasonally higher consumption-related withdrawals.

In a weak environment for client activity, our gross margin declined to 91 basis points. When we published our results last quarter, we flagged that we expected the margin to be impacted by roughly 2 basis points due to the absence of income generated by our strategic investment portfolio.

As lower trading revenues were offset by slightly higher interest income, the remaining decline of 4 basis points came mostly as a result of lower transaction-based fees. The negative effect on the margin was exacerbated by a significant increase in invested assets at the end of the quarter, increasing the average invested assets used to calculate gross margin. For the full year, gross margin increased to 96 basis points from 92 basis points in 2010.

Wealth Management Americas remained the industry leader in financial adviser productivity among our large competitors, reflecting our ability to attract and retain the most productive financial advisers in the industry. Our pre-tax profit of CHF114 million compared with CHF139 million in the third quarter. While revenues rose 2% in francs, they declined 5% in dollars due to lower fees on lower invested asset levels at the end of the third quarter and a decrease in commissions reflecting lower client activity.

In addition, net interest income declined as the third quarter benefited from a reclassification related to mortgage-backed securities in our available-for-sale portfolio. Excluding this, net interest income increased, reflecting higher balances in client securities-based lending and mortgages. Costs, adjusted for restructuring charges, decreased 2% in dollars, as we saw a $14 million decline in litigation provisions and lower legal fees.

We added 54 financial advisors in the quarter. A combination of targeted recruiting of experienced advisors, selected hiring of new financial advisors and continued low attrition levels. Net new money inflows were CHF1.9 billion compared to CHF4 billion in the prior quarter, driven by recruitment of experienced financial advisors. Including dividends and interest, net new money was consistent, at CHF7.9 billion.

WMA continued to make progress on its strategic banking initiatives, with the majority of the growth in lending balances coming from credit lines to our targeted high net worth and ultra-high net worth client base. Net interest income when adjusted for our third quarter reclassification related to mortgage-backed securities in our available-for-sale portfolio increased 2% in dollars on higher client balances and securities-based lending and mortgages as we continued to grow banking product balances with appropriate risk-adjusted pricing.

In a challenging environment, the IB reported a loss for the quarter of CHF256 million. This included a loss on own credit of CHF71 million and a CHF106 million charge for the UK Bank levy. Adjusted for these items, the loss was CHF79 million. Despite reporting a loss, the Investment Bank's underlying performance included bright spots in a number of areas, especially given the difficult market environment in the fourth quarter.

In light of such market conditions, we took a prudent approach to risk taking and focused our efforts on risk-weighted asset reduction. During the quarter, we successfully reduced the overall risk in our core Investment Bank. Our average value at risk for the quarter was CHF36 million, the lowest level in the last three years. At the same time, the revenues per unit of VaR were the highest since the second quarter of 2010, reflecting more efficient deployment of risk in our trading businesses.

While revenues excluding own credit and the unauthorized trading incident increased quarter-on-quarter, they were down approximately 30% year-on-year, both in francs and dollars, reflecting lower revenues across all business areas.

Adjusted for restructuring charges and the UK Bank levy, operating expenses decreased 7% year-on-year. This mostly reflects the favorable effects of the strengthening Swiss franc, as well as reduced variable compensation and our cost reduction program.

Revenues in equities declined 26% year-on-year in Swiss francs and 21% in U.S. dollars. Cash, derivatives and equity-linked revenues were all affected by a significant reduction in volumes and client activity in all regions. In cash, we held up market share despite a decline in revenues. Trading revenues were difficult to generate, although we did see a strong performance in Asia-Pacific. Prime Services had another solid quarter with improved revenues, particularly in the clearing business.

Other equities revenues were $65 million, driven primarily by proprietary trading revenues. We're planning to exit this successful business line, as per our strategy announced on Investor Day, and we're currently exploring ways to realize its value, including as part of Global Asset Management.

Our overall performance in equities was broadly in line with that of our competitors and we maintained our leading positions in most areas. We remain focused on this business as we build on our strengths, and we aim to grow market share as we leverage the knowledge gained from our experience in building our successful electronic FX platform.

In fixed income, revenues rebounded from a very weak third quarter when we recorded losses in credit in emerging markets. Year-on-year revenues decreased 13% in Swiss francs, or 8% in U.S. dollars. Combined revenues in Macro, Credit and Emerging Markets increased 36% year-on-year in U.S. dollars.

Our Macro business delivered another strong performance. Revenues more than doubled from the fourth quarter a year ago. Rates revenues increased fourfold, driven by high volatility and our favorable positioning, particularly at the short end.

In FX, increased volumes on our enhanced electronic trading platform benefited our revenues. Our platform continues to help increase our market share, as we saw volumes in algorithmic trading of spot FX triple since the first quarter of 2011, outpacing general market growth. We believe we've strengthened our top-tier position in FX, as evidenced by client rankings. We also performed well in options and precious metals.

Our Credit business continued to be impacted by market uncertainties, resulting in reduced client activity and increased illiquidity. This is also one of the areas where we actively reduced our trading-risk exposures. We recorded lower mark-to-mark losses than in the third quarter, but higher than a year ago. We saw positive contributions from Structured Credit, Leveraged Capital Markets and Corporate Lending.

Emerging Markets revenues were stable year-on-year. We saw good results in Credit and Structured Products in the Latin America region and also in Foreign Exchange in Europe and in Asia. We reported negative revenues of approximately CHF450 million in other FICC. This included a loss of CHF160 million on our residual risk positions, mostly due to increased credit valuation adjustments on tightening credit spreads on monoline CDS hedges. Also, we recorded a negative debit valuation adjustment on derivatives of almost CHF200 million. Commodities revenues increased versus the prior year.

IBD revenues before risk management charges were $574 million this quarter. Low market activity levels globally continued from the third into the fourth quarter and were significantly lower than a year ago. Led by strong performances in Asia and the Americas, our Advisory business performed well, with slightly increased revenues year-on-year in an environment where the overall fee pool declined. This performance was supported by our private funds group revenues, which increased significantly. These revenues are not captured in Dealogic market share calculations. Notable transactions in the quarter included our advisory role for Peabody Energy's acquisition of Macarthur Coal and advising Suramericana on its purchase of ING Latin America's pension fund asset.

Capital markets revenues declined due to very low levels of activity. Equity capital markets revenues roughly declined in line with the overall fee pool, as we participated in 7 out of the top 20 deals. In addition to low volumes in general, fixed income capital markets revenues were impacted by our selective participation in leverage-financed deals. We believe the fee pool will be driven by the macro environment in the near term and we feel that we are well-positioned for when the markets fully open and confidence returns.

Moving on to Global Asset Management. Profitability improved nearly 50%, to CHF118 million compared with the third quarter. Revenues improved 16% on higher net management fees, driven by improved market valuations and currency effects, as well as incremental revenues from the acquisition of ING Investment Management's business in Australia. Performance fees were CHF15 million higher, primarily in alternative and quantitative investments, which recovered well following a difficult third quarter.

Nearly CHF18 billion of funds in A&Q, out of a total of CHF26 billion which are eligible for performance fees, were within 5% of their high-water marks at the end of the year. Under more normalized market conditions, we believe there is scope for an increase in performance fees in this business. Operating expenses were 7% higher, mostly due to higher personnel expenses on the division's improved performance and the ING acquisition.

Gross margin improved to 34 basis points from 30 basis points due to the higher performance fees I mentioned. Net new money inflows from third parties, excluding money markets, were CHF300 million compared to CHF1.5 billion in the previous quarter.

Also excluding money markets, total net new money outflows of CHF800 million were recorded from clients of our Wealth Management businesses. Outflows were partially offset by CHF2.9 billion of net new money related to the transfer of investment responsibility for private equity fund-to-fund assets from WM&SB which are now recorded as invested assets in both business divisions.

Retail & Corporate had a resilient performance considering the operating environment. Excluding the CHF289 million gain from the sale of our strategic investment portfolio in the third quarter and restructuring charges in both quarters, the pre-tax profit remained stable. Operating income in the quarter held up on an adjusted basis, as lower credit loss expenses offset the decline in revenues due to compression in our interest margin. Operating expenses remained stable when adjusted for restructuring charges.

Deposits grew in the quarter to CHF118 billion, while loans declined to CHF135 billion. Our interest margin fell 8 basis points, driven by the absence of revenues related to the strategic investment portfolio as well as lower rates on our replication portfolio, due to the persistently low interest rate environment.

Now that I've covered all of our business divisions, I'd like to spend some time on costs for the group. Group operating expenses were down slightly in the quarter, due to lower restructuring charges. Excluding restructuring charges, non-personnel expenses rose 22%, mainly due to the CHF109 million expense for the UK Bank levy, higher professional fees and currency effects.

Excluding restructuring charges, personnel expenses remained flat, as the reduction in variable compensation expenses was offset by currency effects. Year-over-year, costs were down over CHF2 billion, aided by the strengthening Swiss franc, lower personnel expenses due to lower accruals for variable compensation and our cost savings program. As can be seen from this chart, all of our main operating expense lines were lower in 2011, except for amortization of prior year awards, which increased slightly.

The bonus pool for 2011 was CHF2.6 billion, which is a 40% decrease from 2010. Most of the decline was in the Investment Bank, which saw a reduction of approximately 60%. The IFRS bonus expense for the performance year 2011 was CHF1.8 billion. This excludes approximately CHF700 million of deferred awards for 2011 which will be recognized in the future. Adding the bonus expense for 2011 to CHF1.6 billion of amortization for prior-year awards, we arrive at the 2011 IFRS expense of CHF3.4 billion, which is 17% lower than 2010. It highlights the challenge of reducing current year total variable compensation expenses.

As of the year-end, the total amount of deferred compensation to be amortized in 2012 and later years was CHF1.7 billion. Furthermore, we intend to grant special plan awards to selected personnel in key areas of strategic focus in the Investment Bank. These awards will be share-based, vest after three years and contain even stricter forfeiture conditions upon departure than existing equity plans.

Including these awards, the total deferred compensation to be amortized in the future is CHF2 billion, compared with CHF2.8 billion at the end of 2010. We reduced the amount of amortization of deferred awards by CHF0.5 billion, from 2011's CHF1.6 billion to CHF1.1 billion.

We had a higher-than-normal tax rate in the quarter and recorded a tax expense of CHF189 million, of which CHF105 million are related to taxable profits. We recorded a tax expense of CHF99 million with respect to the amortization of previously-recognized DTAs in Switzerland. We also recorded a tax expense of CHF41 million in the quarter, following a reduction of the corporate tax rate and changes to loss offset rules in Japan, which led to a remeasurement of our DTAs in that country.

As you'll recall, we had a number of adjustments due to the annual DTA remeasurement we conducted in the third quarter. We had already booked the majority of these adjustments in the third quarter and the remaining CHF56 million net benefit was booked this quarter. For 2012, we expect an effective tax rate in the range of 20% to 25%, excluding any potential effects from the annual DTA remeasurement process in the second half of 2012.

This slide shows a summary of our exposure to sovereign, local governments, bank and other counterparties in Eurozone countries rated lower than AAA by at least one major rating agency, including France and Austria, which were downgraded in January. Our exposure to Italy increased slightly from the prior quarter, mainly due to the UniCredit rights issue underwriting, where we acted as a joint book runner. This transaction has been successfully completed. Our exposure to Spain also increased slightly from the prior quarter. This was mainly due to a more conservative representation of the risk for certain collateralized loans for the purpose of country reporting.

With respect to France, regardless of the change in its credit rating, we're not concerned about our exposure, given the strength and scale of its economy and the quality of our corporate client base. Overall, the vast majority of our exposure in all these countries are in traded products and tradable assets, which are carried at fair market value. Our disclosures reflect our ongoing and careful monitoring of country-risk exposures and we hope you find the expanded information we have provided to be useful. Additional details can be found in our Quarterly Report starting on page 42.

As a result of both increased capital and reduced RWAs, our Basel 2.5 Tier 1 ratio improved nearly 300 basis points, to 16% at the end of the year, with our core Tier 1 ratio at 14.1%. On the right-hand side of this slide, as we showed you at Investor Day, you'll see updated pro-forma Basel 3 common equity Tier 1 ratio estimates, both on a phased-in basis and also as if the Basel 3 rules of 2019 were fully applied today.

Under the phased-in scenario, we would have finished the year with a ratio of approximately 10.8%, already above the regulatory minimum requirement of 10% in Switzerland and advancing towards our own targeted level of 13%. This ratio also highlights our strong capital and competitive positioning. In line with the plans we presented at Investor Day, in the near term, we'll begin our program to fill the gap of up to 6% of the 19% Swiss total capital ratio requirement by issuing a form of low-trigger, loss-absorbing capital.

In summary, we reported a net profit of CHF400 million in the fourth quarter. While it was a modest result in a very challenging quarter, there were several bright spots, including the continued positive net new money from our Wealth Management businesses, Retail & Corporate's resilient performance and Global Asset Management's improved profitability.

And our Investment Bank, Macro, Advisory and Prime Services performed well. We made good progress on the execution of the strategy we announced at our Investor Day, as we reduced RWAs significantly with limited P&L impact. Our cost reduction program is on track and we remain vigilant on cost. Our capital liquidity and funding positions are sound and we remain one of the best capitalized banks in the world.
Thank you. And Sergio and I will now take questions from analysts, first on the phone and then in the room, before moving on to journalists.
First question from the phone from Mr. Huw van Steenis, Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, sir.

Good morning, thanks a lot. I'm just interested to probe a little bit further on your risk-weighted asset reduction program. Obviously, you've refined your thinking over the last three months. You've been able to take down the longer term target and move faster. Do you think there's further potential for you to move faster and further and that maybe in six months' time we might have an even lower target?

And then related to that, number two. As Sergio, as you think about the potential for dividends, at what point do you feel comfortable to make a material increase in dividends? Do you think it could be potentially within the schedule this year or it's more likely to be the next year or beyond that? Thank you.

Thank you. I think that when we look at our risk reduction program, it's clearly highlighting our determination to progress and take any opportunities. Having said that, it would be extremely dangerous to extrapolate the work we have been doing in the last quarter into the foreseeable future. So we keep our confidence in our ability to execute our plan. I think it's premature to talk about an acceleration of this because as you know, market condition and economic consideration are factors that we need to take in consideration.

In respect to dividend, again it's premature to talk about that. If we are able to make progress, we will review our policy. But as we stand, it's premature. I think that's again, we want to highlight our determination about restating our policy of dividend, returning capital to shareholders, but it's absolutely premature to talk about changes on what we announced in November.
Okay, thank you.
Next question from Mr. Kian Abouhossein, JPMorgan. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes, hi. Few questions, first of all, on restructuring. To me, it looks like based on slide six, you only have another CHF17 billion of risk-weighted asset reduction to come and on cost cutting. So I'm just trying to see, should we assume that the CHF45 billion could be actually much larger in terms of risk-weighted asset reduction already in 2012?

Tom?

This year, will the actual program to reduce cost be sufficient to get that number down? And if not, what are the actions that you are preparing? Could we have the number of how much – what extent were the costs on that, because this is the question, how much of it cost to reduce risk-weighted assets in such dimensions? Thank you.

Yes, I think, as we announced, our target for the group in terms of cost-income ratio will be in the range of 65% to 75%. Of course, we are very focused on understanding the nature of the top-line developments. We think that this is a temporary situation. If we get signs that the Q4 environment is likely to become more of a secular change, of course, we're going to need to tackle, first of all, cost by addressing general and admin expenses issues, compensation issues, maybe staffing issues, anything that we can do from a tactical standpoint of view to react to this situation.

But most importantly, we will go through the process – we are going through the process of understanding how can we fundamentally change the cost base of our organization regardless of top-line developments. So in a structural way, to create a capacity to face headwinds in this situation, but also if it's not the case, to create a competitive advantage and value for our shareholders. So it's going to be a combination.

I think that as I mentioned before, that's the reason why we are already thinking about how to create the next buffer. In a more structural way, industrialized processes share best practices within the organization and learn from other industries that have been able to tackle this issue of reducing the cost base regardless of what's going on on the top line.

I don't think that, clearly, we cannot respond to tension on our top line simply by saying we should sell or exit or lose some things. We are in a job to address the problems and fix the problems, not to get rid of problems or buy some things to fix a problem. That's what we are focused on.

On Adoboli, our wish was clearly to try to be more transparent and talk about what happened. Unfortunately, as you know, the investigations and the criminal proceedings are still open.
